definition: C or c is the third letter of the English alphabet
In music, C is the first note in the scale of C major
A cab is a taxi.
example: If you miss the last ferry, catch a cab home

definition: A cabbage is a vegetable with a short stem and a large round centre
example: It has crinkly leaves that are tightly folded over each other.  It is used in salads, especially to make coleslaw

definition: A cackle is a loud, harsh laugh, like the noise a hen makes after laying an egg
note: ... WORD FAMILY verb[cf1] cackle The hens were cackling in the yard.

definition: A cadet is a young person who is being trained for a particular job.
note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective[cf1] cadet Rasha's a cadet journalist with a large city newspaper.[j35]noun[cf1] cadetship All our cadetships for next year are filled.
example: My brother's a naval cadet. [j33] The company takes on half ~a dozen management cadets each year

definition: If someone cadges something such as food or money from you, they get you to give it to them.  Often it is supposed to be a loan, but they don't intend to repay it.
example: I'm not going to lend you any more money[j4]you still owe me the $20 you cadged off me last week

definition: If a pregnant woman has a caesarean section, she has an operation in which her abdomen and uterus are cut open and the baby is taken out
A cafe is a small restaurant where you can buy light meals and drinks
A cafeteria is an inexpensive restaurant or snack bar
example: Usually it is self-service.  Large companies, factories and depart~ ment stores often have a cafeteria for their employees or customers

definition: ' A cage is a box made of wire or metal bars where birds and animals are some~ times kept
note: ... WORD FAMILY verb[cf1] cage ...to cage a wild animal.[j35] adjective[cf1] caged ...caged animals.

definition: ' If someone is cagey, they are unwilling to talk about a particular subject and they act as if they are keeping something secret.
note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb[cf1] cagily [j35]noun[cf1] caginess
example: She's been so cagey about her exams that I'm beginning to wonder if she failed

senses.definition: piece of cake' [cf1]In informal language, if you say that something is a piece of cake, you mean that it is very easy.
example: Would you like a slice of cake? [j33] He brought a plate of small cakes. [j33] ...a birthday cake
We need a new cake of soap in the shower
I know you want to travel and you also like having money in the bank, but you can't have your cake and eat it too
Louise thought the maths test was a piece of cake
sell like hot cakes' [cf1]If you say that something is selling like hot cakes, you mean that it is very popular and people are buying a lot of it

senses.definition: ' If someone is capable of doing something, they have it in them to do it. They do it sometimes, or it's possible that they may do it.
example: I wouldn't hesitate to put her in charge[j4] she's very capable. [j33] We need a capable manager to run the project. [j33] He's a capable administrator, but not very inspired

note: ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] capability (capabilities) I only want a chance to show my real capabilities.

senses.definition: ' If you do something in a certain capacity, you do it in that role.
example: The crate has a capacity of ten cubic metres. [j33] The new stadium has a capacity of 50 000. [j33] What's the engine capacity of your car? [j33] The hall ~was filled to capacity[j4]people were standing
The printer has a maximum capacity of fifty sheets per minute. [j33] We need new equipment to increase our production capacity
I'm constantly amazed at his capacity for beer[j4] anyone else would be dead drunk by now. [j33] She has great capacity for hard work
He has the capacity to do well, but he doesn't try. [j33] She has great capacity for success
In my capacity as chairman, I should like to welcome you all. [j33] I'm not here in my official capacity, but just on a private visit
note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective[cf1] capacity' The final was played in front of a capacity crowd.

senses.ps: I'll make a carbon copy of my lecture notes for you. (b) '[cf2]
senses.definition: carbon copy (a) A carbon copy of a page of writing is a copy of it that you make using carbon paper.  A carbon copy is also something that's exactly the same as something else, or only a little different from it.
example: Coal, graphite and diamonds are made ~of it, and all organic compounds contain it
These new proposals are a carbon copy of what they tried to do three years ago. [j33] Rosalie's a carbon copy of her sister
carbon dioxide Carbon dioxide is a colourless gas which forms a major part of the air we breathe.  It is used in industry to refrigerate things and to make fizzy drinks
carbon monoxide Carbon [chmonoxide is a colourless poisonous gas.  It is contained in car exhaust fumes

carbon paper Carbon paper is paper coated on one side with fine carbon particles.  You put it between two sheets of paper with the carbon side down, so that when you write or type on the top sheet the carbon comes off on the bottom sheet to make a copy

senses.ps: I'll bring the car keys in case we want to go for a drive. [j33] Pack some ointment in case of insect bites. [j33] I'll ~take a sweater just in case[j4]it may turn cooler.  b In case'
senses.definition: in case (a) You use in case to explain that you do something because of something that may happen. You want to be prepared if it does happen.   also means 'for fear that'.  You use it to explain that you act in a certain way to avoid bad consequences that may happen if you don't.
example: I bought a case of oranges at the fruit market today. [j33] A case of wine contains twelve bottles
I'll probably come in June, or in any case before the end of July
I was nervous about using the computer in case I broke it. [j33] I didn't mention the party in case she hadn't been invited. [j33] I thought I'd better tell you in case you hadn't heard

senses.definition: make certain (a) If you make certain of something, you check it again to be absolutely sure.  If you make certain that something happens, you take action to ensure that it does happen.
example: I'm certain it's here somewhere. [j33] 'It's on the 20th.'  'Are you certain?' [j33] She seemed very certain about it. [j33] I'm not certain where he is. [j33] You need to be certain of your facts. 2' [cf2]adjective [cf1]If something is certain, it will definitely happen.  [cf2]His re-election seems certain now. [j33] She's certain to object. [j33] It's not certain that he'll be there. 3a' [cf2]adjective [cf1]You can use certain to refer to something particular without specifying it precisely, because you don't know exactly, or it's not relevant to what you're saying.  [cf2]He only comes into the office on certain days each week. [j33] They made certain calculations and came up with the answer
I know for certain that's not true. [j33] I can't remember for certain, but I think it was Paul
He won't be late.  I'll make certain of that.  I'll put him on the bus myself. [j33] We must make certain that there's no delay
note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY adverb [cf1]See certainly'.[j35] noun certainty (certainties)' He'll be there[j4]that's a certainty.  I can state that with absolute certainty.

senses.definition: chain reaction' [cf1]A chain reaction occurs when a series of related events happens, with each one being caused by the one before it.
example: She has a lovely gold chain which she wears round her neck. [j33] The dog was snarling and straining at its chain. [j33] The back gate is fastened with a chain and padlock
She works for one of the leading supermarket chains
The panic set off a chain reaction in the crowd, and several people were badly trampled

senses.ps: We beat England, but against China we don't stand a chance. [j33] The whole house burnt down in seconds[j4]they never stood a chance.  [j30] ... WORD FAMILY [cf2]adjective
senses.definition: stand a chance' [cf1]If you say that someone doesn't stand a chance, you mean that they have no possibility of success.   chance
example: I first met him by chance at a party. [j33] It was pure chance that she happened to be there
I chanced to look up just as he was passing
Now's your chance to really impress them. [j33] It was the chance of a lifetime. [j33] Please don't dismiss me[j4]give me another chance. [j33] You have three chances to guess the correct number
I took a big chance in changing jobs, but it's worked out very well. [j33] He may not like it, but I'll just have to take that chance
It's not very likely, but there's still a chance. [j33] I clung to the remote chance of success
This may not work, but I'll chance it. [j33] Jane's really chancing it, being late for work so often
That chance meeting led to a close friendship

senses.ps: I'm glad we've cleared up that misunderstanding. (b) '
senses.definition: 6 clear up (a) If you clear up a problem or a disagreement, you resolve it so that it doesn't cause difficulties any more.  If you clear up, you tidy things away.  You put everything back in its correct place.
example: Her lectures are always very clear. [j33] The book is illustrated with clear diagrams. [j33] Let me try again to make myself clear
I'm still not clear about fractions. [j33] Are you clear what you have to do? [j33] I want you to be quite clear that this mustn't happen again
His message contained a clear ~promise of support. [j33] My instructions on this point were quite clear. [j33] They refused to give a clear guarantee not to raise prices
She writes in a clear, bold hand
He poured the liquid into a clear glass bottle. [j33] The water is beautifully clear
We woke up to a lovely clear spring day
It's time we cleared out the attic
We were too tired to clear up after dinner. [j33] Clearing up after the floods will take months
note: ... WORD FAMILY noun [cf1]See clarity. [j35]adverb[cf1] clearly This one is clearly superior.  Clearly,  you can't go back there.[j35]noun [cf1]See clearance'.

senses.definition: ' Clearance is the distance between one object and another that passes underneath or beside it.

example: Have you got clearance from the council to put up that fence? [j33] The pilot received clearance from the control tower and took off
You can pay extra for special clearance[j4]that way you'll be able to withdraw the money sooner

senses.definition: ' A column is also a piece of writing by a particular person which appears regularly in a newspaper or maga~ zine.
example: The story got three columns in today's paper. [j33] The price is given in the last column of the table

definition: If someone is in a coma, they are unconscious for a long while, usually because of a severe accident or illness.
example: Mary was in a coma for three weeks after the accident

senses.definition: ' If you combat something, you fight against it and try to resist it.
example: The Russian and American chess players were in combat for days
He is always trying to combat his craving for sweet things. [j33] Both candidates vowed to combat rising crime. [j33] Tough new regulations are being introduced to combat pollution
note: ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] combatant  'times,0'[cp8.5][j24]k[j16]m[cf1]b[j17]t[j17]nt'  Two hundred combatants perished in the battle.[fj [j35]adjective[cf1] combative  'times,0'[cp8.5][j24]k[j16]m[cf1]b[j17]t[j11]v'  She was unne~ [chcessarily combative in her response to the proposal.

example: Pink and yellow is a horrible combination

example: Pink and yellow is a horrible combination

definition: A combination lock is a special lock that you can only open by turning its control according to a particular sequence of letters or numbers
If you combine two or more things or if they combine, they become joined together to form a single thing.
note: ... WORD FAMILY noun [cf1]See combination'.
example: If you combine yellow and blue, you get green. [j33] The two parties combined to increase their share of the vote. [j33] This dish combines sweet and spicy ingredients

comment: verb forms comes, came, come, coming

senses.ps: Most of our pupils come from the inner city. [j33] My mother comes from Sicily and my father comes from Crete. 11 come over'
senses.definition: (b)' [cf1]If you come up with something that is needed, you provide it unexpectedly.
example: Come over here, please. [j33] Marius hasn't come into work today
I hope the bus comes soon. [j33] The waiter finally came to our table to take our order
Will you come to dinner with me? [j33] I'm afraid I won't be able to come to your party. [j33] People came from all over the country to see the exhibition
Her hair comes to just below her shoulders. [j33] The water came half way up the wall
At last my birthday came. [j33] The time has come to make a decision. [j33] Christmas is coming soon
At last she came into sight at the top of the hill
I came across an old photo of you last week. [j33] In all my long experience I've never come across a similar case
If the committee can't persuade anyone to come forward with financial support, they may have to drop the idea
Why are you acting so strangely? What has come over you? [j33] A great wave of tiredness came over me
The bill came to over $500
Melinda came up with a plan to persuade Martin to stay on at school
There was nothing to eat until Maria came up with some bread and cheese that she'd picked up at the shops. [j33] If they don't come up with a payment soon we'll have to stop their account

Poverty and poor health comprise a situation of grave disadvantage

senses.definition: ' If someone compromises something, they do some~ thing which puts it in doubt or danger.
example: Company and union leaders have worked out a compromise to end the strike. [j33] The renovations turned out to be a compromise between the architect's ideas and what we could afford
We mustn't compromise quality for the sake of saving time. [j33] He refused to compromise his art in the interests of commercial success. [j33] We would never compromise the children's safety

senses.definition: ' Compulsion is forcing someone to do something.
example: She suffered from a compulsion to eat vast quantities of food and then vomit. [j33] I felt a sudden compulsion to confront him with the truth
There is no compulsion for you to join the health fund, but it offers good benefits. [j33] With no element of compulsion, the voluntary code of practice proved unworkable
note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective [cf1]See compulsory.

definition: If something is compulsory, you have to do it whether you want to or not.  You have no choice about it.
note: ... THE OPPOSITE [cf1]of this is optional.
example: In Australia voting is compulsory for all citizens

definition: If you compute some~ thing, you calculate it.  You work it out using maths.
example: I computed that he'd spent over $1000 on drink over the year

definition: A computer is an electronic machine that can do mathematical calculations and can store, rearrange and give out information very quickly

senses.definition: ' A comrade is a close friend or companion.
example: All Pierre's old war comrades were at the service
' The word comrade is also used to refer to someone who belongs to a socialist or communist party
note: ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] comradeship

definition: In informal language, a con is a trick where someone deceives you in order to gain something for themselves.
note: ... WORD FAMILY verb[cf1] con (con, conned, conning) They conned us into agreeing to help them.
example: Elise gave the man $100, but she later found out that the whole story was a big con. [j33] He claimed that his political rivals were guilty of a massive con on the electorate

definition: If some~ thing is concave, it curves inwards.
example: After weeks of starvation, his cheeks were concave

senses.definition: ' If you conceal something such as facts or emotions, you keep them secret from other people.
example: I concealed the letter under a pile of papers when she entered the room. [j33] The wallet is concealed in a drawer at the back of the desk

note: ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] concealment

senses.definition: ' In rather formal language, if you say someone concedes, you mean that they give up.

senses.definition: ' If something concerns you, it is relevant to you or involves you.

senses.definition: of course Of course means 'naturally'.  When you say this you mean that you assume the person you are addressing already knows or understands what you are telling them.
example: Their fixed menu is $25 for two courses or $32 for three. [j33] We were served a banquet of seven courses
I'm doing a word processing course
The race is run over a 15 km course. [j33] The course this year is especially challenging. [j33] Only one third of the entrants were able to complete the course
I decided not to intervene, but to let matters follow their course. [j33] What is the normal course of events in such a case? [j33] We have several possible courses of action open to us
Of course it's been a difficult time for him. [j33] I don't want to rush you of course. [j33] You must of course be familiar with this part of the country

senses.definition: out of court If a legal matter is settled out of court, it is resolved by an agreement between the parties before the case is due to be heard in court.
example: The accused's mother attended court on every day of the trial
The court of a king or queen is their palace and all the people who live and work there
The apartments have their own swimming pool and tennis court
A court is an area enclosed by buildings on several sides
They settled our claim out of court rather than face the embarrassment of a public hearing
note: ... ANOTHER WORD [cf1]for this is courtyard.   5 'verb [cf1]In rather old-fashioned language, if you say that someone courts someone else, you mean that ~they try to win their love.  Frank has been courting Emily for months, but she's just not interested.

senses.ps: The government was accused of covering up the scandal. 12 cover for'
senses.definition: 1 cover up If you cover something up, you try to stop other people from finding out about it.   If you cover for someone, you do their work while they are away.
senses.rest: Wh@'s g@i:ng t@ c@vEr f@r Da:si:a: whi:lE shE's @n ma:tErni:ty lEa:vE?
example: We covered the stain on the carpet with a rug. [j33] I'd better cover that jug to keep the flies out. [j33] She covered her books with plastic. [j33] You should keep your head covered in the sun
Snow covered the hills. [j33] Dust covered the furniture. [j33] The children came home covered in mud. [j33] The walls were covered with mould
The oil spill covered ten square kilometres of the coastal water. [j33] The factory covers about a hectare of land
My health insurance covers me for private hospitals. [j33] We have our house and contents fully covered
We covered 900 km in two days
We've already covered what to do in an emergency. [j33] Now, is there anything I haven't covered? [j33] Not all the news programs covered the story
He took the cover off his tennis racquet and walked onto the court
I glanced at the cover of the magazine and decided not to buy it. [j33] ...the front cover. [j33] ...the back cover
The children ran for cover from the storm. [j33] We dived for cover as the bullets began to fly. [j33] I'd like to be able to keep my car under cover

example: You wish that you had it

senses.definition: Cows are farm animals which are raised either to produce milk or to be slaughtered for beef
example: In particular, a cow is a female animal of this kind
A female elephant, seal or whale can also be called a cow

definition: A coward is someone who is not brave.  They are afraid and unwilling to face danger or difficult experiences.
note: ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] cowardice
example: Don't be such a coward[j4]it'll only hurt for a moment

definition: A crab is a sea creature with a hard shell
example: It has ten legs, with large claws on the front pair.  Some types can be cooked and the flesh inside the shell eaten as food

senses.ps: She cracked up under the strain. [j33] You can't work fifteen hours a day indefinitely without cracking up. (b)  '[cf2]verb phrase
senses.definition: 2 crack up (a)  In informal language, if you say someone cracks up, you mean that they have a mental breakdown.  In informal English, if you say someone cracks up, you mean that they can't help laughing.
example: The cup cracked in the dishwasher. [j33] You'll crack the glass if you pour boiling water into it
The cracking of the twigs indicated that someone was ~approaching. [j33] The stockman cracked his whip
I cracked my knee on the table as I walked past. [j33] The old lady cracked him on the head with her umbrella
I stared at the puzzle for ages before I finally cracked it
Even though he was so ill, he was still cracking jokes
I threw this plate away as there was a crack right across it
The coin rolled down a crack in the floor. [j33] I managed to wedge myself into a crack in the rocks
We all heard the crack of the gun
He gave his egg a sharp crack on the edge of the table
I'm sick of her cracks about my weight

senses.definition: A cracker is a thin, crisp, savoury biscuit.
example: They served cheese and crackers with the wine
Crackers are also small fireworks that make a loud noise when you let them off

senses.definition: A cracker is a thin, crisp, savoury biscuit.
example: They served cheese and crackers with the wine
Crackers are also small fireworks that make a loud noise when you let them off

definition: If something crackles, it makes short sharp sounds.
note: ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] crackle
example: The fire was crackling in the fireplace. [j33] The parcel crackled when I squeezed it

definition: The crackling on pork is the fat which has become crisp when it is cooked
A cradle is a small bed for a baby that you can rock from side to side.
note: ... WORD FAMILY verb[cf1] cradle He cradled the child in his arms and sang it a lullaby.
example: The young mother sat rocking her baby in its cradle

senses.definition: You can also refer to a ship or plane as a craft.
example: The college offers courses in various crafts such as weaving and pottery
The captain brought his craft right up to the wharf

example: The college offers courses in various crafts such as weaving and pottery
The captain brought his craft right up to the wharf

definition: If someone is crafty, they are cunning. They are clever and rather devious in achieving what they want.
example: It was pretty crafty of him to get out of the office by offering to deliver the package

definition: A crag is a rough steep rock sticking out from a cliff or mountain
note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective[cf1] craggy ...a craggy moun~ tain top.

senses.definition: In informal language, if you say that you cram for a test or exam, you mean that you work very hard just before it.
example: She crammed her clothes into a suitcase and left at once. [j33] We all crammed into a tiny room. [j33] He was determined to cram as much as possible into each day
He lazed around all year and then crammed madly for three weeks before the exams

definition: Cramp is a sudden painful stiffening of the muscles.
note: ... WORD FAMILY verb[cf1] cramp The muscles in my arm cramped painfully.
example: She had to pull out of the race because of a cramp in her leg. [j33] The doctor was called to see a patient suffering from stomach cramps

definition: If something is cramped, it is crowded or squashed up.  There isn't enough room.
example: The office was far too cramped for us all to work effectively. [j33] It was pretty cramped with twelve of us in the house over Christmas. [j33] Her writing was cramped and hard to read

senses.definition: If you crane your neck, you stretch it out as far as you can in order to see something.
example: The tree ~blew over in the storm and we needed a crane to remove it
A crane is also a bird with a long neck and long legs
She craned her neck out of the window to see the procession

senses.definition: A crank is a person who has strange ways of thinking and of doing things.
example: Don't listen to her, she's a food crank. [j33] He's a bit of a crank you know[j4]he collects old tins
A crank is also a handle that you turn to start an engine

definition: If you're cranky, you're cross, angry or irritated.
example: Don't worry about him[j4] he's just a cranky old man

senses.definition: A crash is a loud noise that something makes when it falls or collides with something.
example: The plane crash killed two hundred people. [j33] The crash in the tunnel delayed traffic for three hours. [j33] She was crippled in a car crash
The vase crashed to the ground. [j33] The Australian stock market crashed in October 1987
One of the plane's engines caught fire and I was sure we were going to crash. [j33] He drove off the road and crashed into a telegraph pole. [j33] I crashed the car the first time I drove it

The box fell to the ground with a loud crash. [j33] We sat listening to the crash of the waves on the rocks below. 5 crash helmet '[cf2] [cf1]If you ride a bicycle or motorbike you must wear a crash helmet on your head.  The helmet protects your head from injury in case you have an accident

definition: A crate is a container used for transporting things such as fruit or vegetables, or cartons of milk or bottles of beer.
note: ... WORD FAMILY verb[cf1] crate Our furniture was crated up to be sent overseas.
example: We stood on old milk crates to watch the procession

definition: A crater is the mouth of a volcano, or a very large hole in the ground caused by an explosion or something hitting it.
example: Some of us ventured down into the crater where the volcano ~was belching clouds of steam. [j33] The satellite photo~ graphed the craters on the moon

definition: If you crave something, you want it very badly.
note: ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] craving Pregnant women often develop strange cravings.
example: I still occasionally crave a cigarette, even though I gave up smoking months ago

senses.definition: If you crawl, you move forward on your hands and knees.
example: Babies begin to crawl at about seven months. [j33] The injured man crawled to the side of the road. [j33] You should drop to the ground, where the smoke is less dense, and crawl to the exit. 2 '[cf2]verb [cf1]If something such as a car crawls, it moves very slowly.  [cf2]The car crawled up the hill at about ten kilometres an hour. [j33] We spent over an hour crawling along in a traffic dam.  3 '[cf2]verb [cf1]In informal language, if you say someone crawls, you mean that they act very humbly towards someone and flatter them, often because they want something from them.  [cf2]I'll ask him nicely but I refuse to crawl. [j33] It makes me sick the way she's always crawling to the boss
The crawl is a stroke in swimming
note: ... ANOTHER WORD [cf1]for this is freestyle.  [j32] ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] crawl We moved forward at a crawl for about twenty minutes.[j35]noun[cf1] crawler He's such a crawler[j4]he agrees with everything the supervisor says.

definition: A crayfish is an animal that lives in fresh water
example: It has a hard shell and looks rather like a lobster

definition: A crayon is a coloured pencil or a long thin cylinder of pigment that you use for drawing or colouring
A craze is an activity or fashion that suddenly becomes very popular with a lot of people.
example: He's always keen to follow the latest craze

senses.definition: If someone is crazy, they behave in a strange or foolish way.

senses.definition: crop up If something crops up, it happens unexpectedly or by chance.
example: Louisa has had her hair cropped. [j33] I cropped the edges of the photo to fit it on the page
George had to go in to the office on Sunday because a problem cropped up. [j33] The disease isn't common, but cases do crop up occasionally

senses.ps: I'll keep my fingers crossed for you. [j33] Well, fingers crossed, here goes! [j33] I said I'd love to see her again but I had my fingers firmly crossed.  [j30] ... WORD FAMILY [cf2]noun
senses.definition: 1 ' [cf1]If you cross your fingers, you cross your middle finger over your forefinger.  Usually you do this as a sign that you wish for good luck.  Sometimes people do this when they know that they are lying.   crossing
example: She crossed the room to meet him. [j33] The train took four hours to cross the desert. [j33] I crossed the bridge into the old part of the city. [j33] Be careful when you cross the road. 2 '[cf2]verb [cf1]If something crosses a space, it extends from one side of it to the other.  [cf2]The bridge crosses the river at Fisherman's Creek. [j33] This road crosses the Nullarbor Plain
The two roads cross at an intersection a couple of kilometres away
I crossed the sticks in the fireplace and piled up newspaper on top of them
It is safer always to cross your cheques in case they go astray
They were playing noughts and crosses. [j33] My work came back to me covered in red crosses
The show is a cross between straight drama and the circus
I can see by your face that you're cross. [j33] I'm cross that they didn't bother to consult me
The two ministers have crossed swords on the issue before
There's a pedestrian crossing a little further on. [j33] We had a rough crossing
note: ... ANOTHER WORD [cf1]for this is cranky.   9 ' cross out If you cross  something out in a piece of writing, you draw a line through it because you think it is wrong or no longer relevant or you don't agree with it.  I wrote three pages in the exam but I crossed out half of it.

definition: In the Christian religion, the Cross refers to the structure on which Jesus Christ was crucified
'times,0'[cp8.5]kr[j16]s-eg[j24]z[j12][cf1]m[j17]n' If you cross-examine someone, you ask them a lot of detailed questions about something.
example: Counsel for the prosecution cross-examined the witness on her testimony for the defence. [j33] As soon as I get in my mother cross-examines me about where I've been and who I've been with

definition: A crossroads is a place where two roads meet or cross
note: ... ANOTHER WORD [cf1]for this is intersection.

definition: [oi0,(s75+6)]  A crossword or crossword puzzle is a word puzzle where you have to solve clues and write the answers in a grid of squares
example: When you have written some answers in, this helps you because you know certain of the letters in the other words

definition: If you crouch, you bend or stoop down so that you are not so tall or ~conspicuous.
example: We had to crouch to get through the low doorway. [j33] He crouched behind the bookcase when she came in so that she wouldn't see him

definition: A croupier is a person whose job is to work at a gaming table in a club or casino

senses.definition: ' In informal language, if you say someone crows about some~ thing, you mean that they boast or show off about it.  They are very pleased with themselves because of it.
example: He made himself very unpopular by crowing about his victory. [j33] OK, so you were right[j4]there's no need to crow

definition: A crowbar is a heavy iron bar which is used as a lever, for example to force something open.
example: He opened the crate with a crowbar

definition: A crowd is a large number of people in the same place.
note: ... WORD FAMILY verb[cf1] crowd The children crowded around their teacher.  We all crowded into the room.[j35]adjective[cf1] crowded The lecture hall was very crowded.
example: The crowd had been waiting for many hours to see the parade. [j33] I can't stand the crowds in town on Saturday afternoon

senses.definition: The crown of something is the top part of it.
example: When a king or queen is crowned, a crown is put on their head at a special ceremony to show that they have just become the monarch
He insisted that Australia would remain loyal to the Crown
He hit the crown of his head on the beam. [j33] I could see her standing on the crown of the hill
A crown on your tooth is a new false tooth that the dentist has made and fitted over what is left of the old natural tooth

definition: If something is crucial, it is extremely important.
note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY adverb[cf1] crucially ...crucially important.
example: Your decision is crucial to your future, so think carefully about it. [j33] It's crucial that we should win this contract. [j33] She was disciplined by her party for missing the crucial vote

senses.definition: If you say someone or something crucifies you, you mean that they treat you very harshly or make you undergo a very unpleasant experience.
example: This was a common form of execution in the Roman Empire at the time
The barrister absolutely crucified that witness. [j33] We'll be crucified if they catch us here[j4]let's go. [j33] Low income earners have been crucified by rising interest rates
note: ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] crucifixion

senses.definition: If something is described as crude, it is in its raw or natural state.
example: I made several crude attempts at drawing a tree. [j33] The prototype is still relatively crude, but is shows how the software will work
I decided to be really crude and eat with my fingers. [j33] He shocked us all by telling a string of crude jokes
Australia exports crude oil to Japan

definition: If someone is cruel, they enjoy hurting or upsetting people or animals.
note: ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] cruelty
example: Stop beating that poor dog, you cruel beast. [j33] She made some cruel remarks about his performance

senses.definition: If you cruise somewhere, you travel there in a leisurely fashion. You are enjoying yourself and not in a hurry.
example: She won a cruise of the South Pacific in the Easter draw
We were cruising along in the car admiring the scenery
note: ... WORD FAMILY verb[cf1] cruise They went cruising in the Mediterranean.

definition: A crumb is a small piece of something such as bread, cake or biscuit.
example: She swept up the crumbs off the floor. [j33] The recipe uses half a cup of bread crumbs

definition: If something crumbles, it falls apart into small pieces or powder.
example: The old wall is crumbling underneath the ivy. [j33] The paper crumbled to dust as soon as it was exposed to the ~air. [j33] I crumbled the biscuits into the base of the dish

definition: In informal language, if you say something is crummy, you mean that it is very bad.  You do not like it at all.
example: Her flat is really crummy[j4]I'd hate to live there. [j33] It was a crummy movie. [j33] He expected me to work all day for a crummy twenty bucks

definition: A crumpet is a sort of thin, flat bun with lots of holes in it
example: You toast it and eat it with butter

senses.definition: crumple up ' [cf1]If you crumple something up, you screw it up.  You compress it into a very small space.
example: Don't crumple that dress[j4]I have to wear it tonight. [j33] I sat down on her copy of the speech and crumpled it. [j33] I was feeling pretty crumpled by the end of the twenty-hour flight
The floor crumpled under the weight of the machinery. [j33] You can't work fifteen hours a day for long without crumpling under the strain. [j33] Her face crumpled and she began to cry
She crumpled up the letter and threw it into the waste paper basket

note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY verb[cf1] crusade
example: Her crusade against drink driving has occupied most of her energy for years. [j33] At last the campaign crusade was over and we could only wait for the results

senses.definition: If someone is crushed, they are humiliated or disappointed.
example: He crushed the beer can and threw it away. [j33] The car was crushed under the toppled crane. [j33] The rock is crushed to extract the gold. [j33] The crowd crushed me against the barrier
She was crushed by the news of her father's death

I was crushed by his lack of interest in my proposal. 4 '[cf2]noun [cf1]A crush is a large crowd of people.  [cf2]We became separated in the crush. [j33] I did my Christmas shopping early to avoid the crush.  5 '[cf2]noun [cf1]When a young person has a crush on someone, they like them very much and spend a lot of time thinking about them. example: She cut the cake and handed us each a slice. [j33] Could you cut me a slice of cheese? [j33] He always cuts the crossword out of the newspaper. [j33] I cut up the cardboard into small squares
She cut her fingers while chopping up the vegetables. [j33] Cut a notch to show where the other piece should join. [j33] They use tools tipped with diamond to cut the glass
Melanie's father cut her allowance. [j33] I've cut the amount of time I spend on housework. [j33] All the stores will be cutting prices in the January sales
The line AB cuts CD at right angles
I started to speak but he cut me off
Our vacation was cut short by Michael's father's illness
note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY noun[cf1] cut I've got a cut on my foot.  There was a cut in the price of oil.[j35]adjective[cf1] cutting She made a cutting remark about Leon's appearance.

senses.ps: I don't think I'm cut out to be a teacher[j4]I'm too impatient. 7 '

definition: A cynic is someone who distrusts other people and always assumes that they have bad motives.
note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective [cf1]See cynical.
example: Tom is such a cynic[j4]just talking to him is depressing. [j33] In political life it pays to be a cynic

senses.definition: If someone is cynical, they are unscrupulous.  They are willing to exploit other people to gain an advantage for themselves.
example: I was pretty cynical about her motives
It was a cynical attempt to manipulate the voters
note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb[cf1] cynically He laughed cynically.  They cynically took advantage of her inexperience.
